Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2018 Workshop in Analysis and Probability, to be held at Texas A&M University from July 2 to August 19, 2018, will bring together senior and junior researchers and advanced graduate students in analysis and probability and related fields in order to broaden the education of the younger participants and to promote interaction among researchers working in different areas. It will provide support to many researchers not on sponsored research grants who will benefit from being in an environment that is research friendly and from contact with participants who are leaders in the field. An emphasis is put on the support of junior researchers, minorities, women, and graduate students. The main session of the Workshop will take place during the period from July 2 to August 19.Activities sponsored by the Workshop include the three-day general conference SUMIRFAS (Informal Regional Functional Analysis Seminar)to be held from August 17 to 19, the Concentration Week "Noncommutative Geometry and Index Theory for Group Actions and Singular Spaces" to be held from May 21 to 25, and the Concentration Week "Random Walks in Correlated and Dynamic Environments" to be held from August 13 to 17.

The Workshop activities have a wide impact by providing intellectual stimulation for all participants as well as giving an opportunity to a diverse group of junior participants to increase the breadth and depth of knowledge and to interact with senior researchers in several areas of mathematics. There is also significant outreach to applied mathematics and computer science, and indeed an important aspect of the Workshop is to promote cooperation among researchers in different fields. The Concentration Weeks will include introductory lecture series designed to acquaint junior researchers and non-experts with the basics of an area. All Workshop participants will be invited to disseminate their work through seminars. More details are available at http://www.math.tamu.edu/~kerr/workshop/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop brought together senior and junior researchers and graduate students in several areas of analysis and probability as well as some researchers in other fields such as geometry and theoretical computer science with the goal of broadening the education of the younger participants and of promoting interaction among researchers in different areas. The Workshop featured the Concentration Weeks "Random Walks in Correlated and Dynamic Environments" (2018), "Noncommutative Geometry and Index Theory for Group Actions and Singular Spaces" (2018), "Randomness and Determinism in Compressive Data Acquisition" (2019), and "Bellman Function Methods on the Hamming Cube" (2020, held online). The Workshop also included yearly installments of the three-day conference SUMIRFAS (Summer Informal Regional Functional Analysis Seminar) and about ten individual seminar talks each summer, with the exception of 2020 when these activities were canceled due to the pandemic.
The Concentration Weeks included introductory lectures designed to acquaint junior researchers and non-experts with the basics of a discipline as well as advanced lectures for experts. The Concentration Week “Noncommutative Geometry and Index Theory for Group Actions and Singular Spaces” covered topics ranging from index theory on singular spaces and secondary invariants to group actions on aspherical manifolds and the analysis and geometry of hypoelliptic operators. The Concentration Week "Random Walks in Correlated and Dynamic Environments" served as a platform for advancing the theory of random walks in general environments by uniting expertise across various streams and promoting the search for universality phenomena. The Concentration Week “Randomness and Determinism in Compressive Data Acquisition" treated a spectrum of topics related to compressive sensing and data science at large, including pseudorandomness and derandomization, random matrices and high-dimensional probability, metric and linear geometry, semidefinite programming, convex geometry, and dimension reduction. The Concentration Week "Bellman Function Methods on the Hamming Cube" was primarily aimed at graduate students and postdocs and provided an introduction to the main tools, current results, and open problems in the study of functional inequalities on the Hamming cube.

The Workshop activities have had a broad impact by providing intellectual stimulation for all participants as well as giving an opportunity to a diverse group of graduate students and junior researchers to broaden their education across a wide range of topics in functional analysis and related fields (operator theory, probability theory, ergodic theory, statistical mechanics, harmonic analysis, Banach spaces, operator algebras, free probability, noncommutative geometry, and operator spaces) and through a variety of formats, from the lectures series and research talks in the Concentration Weeks to the individual seminars where participants presented and discussed their work in a less formal setting.
